documentId: Understanding Arguments_ An Introduction to Informal Logic (1)
content:
a
sentence of the form “ponly if q” will conversationally imply a commitment
to “pif and only if q.”



174
CHAPTER 6 ■Propositional Logic
We can next look at sentences of the form “pif and only if q“—so-called
biconditionals. If I say that I will clean the barn if and only if Hazel will help
me, then I am saying that I will clean it if she helps and I will not clean it if
she does not. Translated, this becomes:
(H)B) & (~H)~B)
This is equivalent to:
(H)B) & (B)H)
We thus have an implication goi
